0.text:
So something in the Game of Thrones books
that mostly don’t appear in the show are

3.text:
the many dreams and visions that characters
have.

6.text:
They have regular dreams and nightmares about
their hopes and fears and memories, but dreams

12.text: can also be connected to magic and prophecy.

15.text:
Some Starks have wolf dreams, inside the minds
of direwolves, and Targaryens have dragon

22.text:
Red priests see the future and the past in
their flames, Bran and Jojen have greendreams

26.text:
with magic trees, and Quaithe uses glass candles
to enter peoples’ dreams – point being,

32.text:
lots of characters in Game of Thrones have
weird visions, often connecting to the future,

37.text:
past, magic and prophecy, and this is especially
true of Daenerys Targaryen.

43.text:
She has dragon dreams, fever dreams, prophetic
dreams, glass candle dreams, she has a whole

47.text:
vision quest in the Dothraki Sea after eating
some funny berries – but some of the most

52.text:
important and interesting visions in the whole
series are the visions Dany has in the House

59.text:
In Book and Season 2, Daenerys comes to the
city of Qarth and meets a warlock called Pyat

66.text:
He invites her to the House of the Undying
, where he and his warlock buddies live, promising

70.text:
to give Dany great “truth and wisdom”
. In the show, Pyat Pree steals Dany’s dragons

76.text:
to force her to come, but in the books she
goes willingly.

78.text:
She comes the entrance and is offered a potion
called shade of the evening, which Pyat says

83.text:
will open her mind to the truths within . So
Dany takes the drugs offered by the strange

91.text:
It’s a strange, magical place, full of passageways
arranged in impossible ways , and there are

96.text:
“endless” rooms where Dany begins to see
visions.

100.text:
The first vision is the weirdest – Dany
sees “a beautiful woman sprawled naked on

105.text:
the floor while four little men crawl” over
her, biting and fucking her body . This way

110.text:
this is usually interpreted, the woman represents
Westeros, and the four men represent the four

116.text: kings who are ravaging the country with war.

118.text:
It’s kind of a gross metaphor, but it gets
the point across – war is terrible, and

123.text: so, perhaps, are the men who wage it.

126.text:
The reason why there are four men here instead
of all five kings of the War of the Five Kings

130.text:
is probably that King Renly is dead at this
point in the story.

134.text:
Anyway, Dany’s second vision is of “a
feast of corpses”.

138.text:
She sees savagely slaughtered feasters strewn
across overturned furniture, and a dead man

143.text:
with the head of a wolf and an iron crown
. This is pretty clearly the Red Wedding.

148.text:
The dead man is Robb Stark, after the Freys
sew his direwolf’s head onto his corpse.

154.text:
Interestingly, this vision happens a whole
book before the Red Wedding does, so this

158.text:
is a great example of a vision that accurately
shows the future of the story before it happens.

164.text:
Dany’s next vision is of the past – she
sees inside “the house with the red door”,

169.text:
which was a “house in Braavos” where Daenerys
and Viserys lived for a while after they fled

173.text: Westeros when Robert Baratheon took over.

176.text:
In Braavos, Dany and her brother were protected
by Ser Willem Darry, a knight who stayed loyal

181.text:
to the Targaryens until he died of some sickness
. The house with the red door is the closest

186.text:
place Dany has known to a home , and she dreams
of it often as a place of safety and comfort

194.text:
But the house with the red door is also the
subject of conspiracy theories – there’s

197.text:
this whole thing about how the house with
the red door had a lemon tree outside , when

201.text:
trees are very rare in Braavos – so some
people believe the house might actually have

206.text:
been in Dorne, as part of some Martell conspiracy,
though the evidence for this isn’t very

213.text:
Dany’s fourth vision is of her father, the
Mad King Aerys Targaryen, sitting the Iron

220.text:
Aerys says “Let him be the king of ashes”
, and what’s going on here is that, Aerys’

224.text:
army, and son, have just been destroyed by
Robert Baratheon at the Battle of the Trident,

229.text:
so Aerys is giving the order to burn down
King’s Landing so that Robert can’t have

234.text:
it . He would have got away with it too if
it weren’t for – a young Jaime Lannister

238.text: killing the king and saving the city.

242.text:
Dany’s fifth vision is of another dead Targaryen
– her brother Rhaegar, the eldest child

248.text:
In the vision, Rhaegar’s with his wife,
Elia Martell, and their newborn son, who they

254.text:
Rhaegar says that this child Aegon “is the
prince that was promised” . The prince that

258.text:
was promised, or Azor Ahai, is a hero prophesied
to save “the world” . When he was young,

264.text:
Rhaegar believed that he was this hero, but
he later comes to believe it would be his

268.text:
son Aegon . Rhaegar also says “The dragon
has three heads” and “There must be one

275.text:
So at this time, Rhaegar has two kids – a
young daughter, Rhaenys, and now the infant

281.text:
Aegon is the name of Aegon the Conqueror,
the original Targaryen who took over Westeros

287.text:
This Aegon had two sister-wives – Rhaenys
and Visenya – so it looks like Rhaegar was

293.text:
naming his kids after these original three
Targaryens – he just needed a third child,

298.text:
Visenya, to complete set – so that seems
to be what he means when he says “There

303.text:
must be one more” . A problem, though, is
that Rhaegar’s wife Elia was “frail and

308.text:
sickly”, and after the birth of Aegon, the
maesters said she couldn’t have more kids

312.text:
. So Rhaegar had a problem – how was he
gonna have his third child, his third head

317.text: of the dragon, if Elia couldn’t give birth?

320.text:
Maybe this is part of the reason why Rhaegar
ran off with Lyanna Stark.

325.text:
Of course, that led to Robert’s Rebellion,
and the death of Rhaegar, and the deaths of

329.text:
Elia and Rhaenys and Aegon – so, so much
for the prince that was promised and the three

334.text:
heads of the dragon, but with Lyanna, Rhaegar
did get to have his third child – Jon Snow.

343.text:
She encounters strange phantoms that try to
lure her into the wrong room, but she gets

347.text:
through and arrives at the true chamber of
the Undying Ones themselves, a group of immortal

353.text:
warlocks who turn out to look like creepy
blue corpses, there’s a human heart floating

358.text:
above, it’s like some scene from The Binding
of Isaac . And the Undying whisper prophesies

363.text:
to Dany – they say “three fires must you
light … one for life and one for death and

369.text:
“three mounts must you ride … one to bed
and one to dread and one to love”.

375.text:
And “three treasons will you know … once
for blood and once for gold and once for love”.

381.text:
There are lots of different ways to interpret
these lines, but here are some likely answers

384.text:
– the fire to light for life is probably
the fire Dany lights to hatch her dragons,

391.text:
The fire for death could be a bunch of things,
cause Dany often kills people with fire – but

396.text:
it’s probably the fire that Dany’s just
about to use to kill the Undying, to bring

402.text:
The mount to bed is probably “the silver”
horse Dany rides to her first night with Drogo.

407.text:
The mount to dread is probably her dragon
Drogon – who causes such dread in Dany’s

414.text:
Some people interpret this mount thing differently,
arguing that the mounts aren’t literal animals

418.text:
that Dany rides, but they’re the men Dany’s
had sex with – so you could say Hizdahr,

423.text:
or even, potentially, Euron is a mount to
dread, maybe Drogo is the mount to love and

429.text:
Hizdahr is to bed, or something – there
are lots of different arrangements, but what

433.text:
seems to make the most sense is just the silver
and Drogon as Dany’s mounts so far.

439.text:
Now the treasons – the treason for blood,
according to Dany, is when Mirri Maz Duur

444.text:
kills Dany’s unborn child Rhaego to avenge
her people who were killed by the Dothraki

448.text:
. The treason for gold, Dany believes, is
when Jorah reports on her to Varys – but

454.text:
thing is, Jorah doesn’t betray her for gold,
he just wanted a pardon so that he could go

458.text:
home to Westeros . Dany later thinks this
treason is from Brown Ben Plumm, a sellsword

464.text:
captain who betrays her in the books , but
he doesn’t do it for gold either . So maybe

469.text:
the treason for gold is yet to come – maybe
from Daario , or Illyrio , or the Shavepate.

474.text:
Regardless, this leaves a fire to love, a
mount to love and a treason for love.

481.text:
A fire “to love” is interesting wording,
cause the other fires were “for life”,

488.text: Does this mean Dany will love a fire?

493.text:
Well there’s a lot of speculation that Dany
and Jon Snow might fall in love.

497.text:
And Jon could represent fire in that he may
be Azor Ahai, who is said to wield a flaming

502.text: sword , and represents light against darkness.

506.text:
The full wording here is that Dany must light
a fire to love.

509.text:
So maybe Dany will light the fire that makes
Jon Azor Ahai.

514.text:
This could connect to the story of Nissa Nissa
– apparently the original Azor Ahai created

519.text:
his burning sword Lightbringer by plunging
his sword into the body of his wife . If Jon

524.text:
Snow is Azor Ahai, maybe he’ll have to do
something similar with Daenerys, maybe this

531.text:
This is all very vague, but however you look
at it, love and fire and treason seem to be

537.text:
in Dany’s future, and Jon Snow could easily
be a big part of that.

542.text:
And there’s also a mount – so maybe Dany
could ride Ghost?

546.text:
The Undying say some more stuff – they call
Dany “child of storm” and “daughter

551.text:
of death”, which refers to Dany’s birth
– she was born during a storm, and her mother

557.text:
The Undying call her “bride of fire” – which
again could connect to Dany loving someone

562.text:
who symbolically is fire, and they call her
“slayer of lies”, which is an interesting

567.text: one – we’ll get back to this.

569.text:
They call Dany “child of three” which
could just refer to the fact that she’s

572.text:
the youngest of three children, but it could
also connect to more general Targaryen number

577.text:
three shenanigans cause the Undying also say
“three heads has the dragon”.

583.text:
Then the Undying give Dany a bunch more visions
at high speed.

586.text:
She sees her brother Viserys killed with molten
gold by Drogo.

590.text:
She sees “A tall lord with copper skin and
silver-gold hair” standing “beneath the

595.text:
banner of a fiery stallion, a burning city
behind him”.

599.text:
This is a cool one – with the skin of a
Dothraki, and hair of a Targaryen, and a sigil

604.text:
with both a horse and fire, this guy must
be Rhaego, the son of Daenerys and Drogo who

610.text:
was never born cause he was killed in the
womb by the magic of Mirri Maz Duur.

615.text:
This vision is of what Dany’s son would
have become had he lived – because Rhaego

619.text:
was connected to a prophecy of his own – the
dosh khaleen tell Daenerys that her son would

624.text:
be the “the stallion who mounts the world”,
a great Dothraki warrior who’d unite the

628.text:
khalasars and take over the world . But Rhaego
died and the prophecy didn’t come true .

635.text:
Dany then sees “Rubies” flying “like
drops of blood from the chest of a dying prince”.

639.text:
He sinks “to his knees in the water and
with his last breath” murmurs “a woman’s

645.text:
So this guy is Rhaegar Targaryen again, Dany’s
brother.

648.text:
Here he’s dying at the Battle of the Trident,
killed by Robert Baratheon during his Rebellion.

653.text:
The big question here is whose name does Rhaegar
murmur?

657.text: Maybe he named his wife, Elia Martell.

659.text:
But maybe he named Lyanna Stark, the woman
he had just run off with and started this

664.text:
war over in the first place . We’re told
by some characters that Rhaegar abducted and

669.text:
raped Lyanna, but many readers suspect that
Rhaegar and Lyanna were actually in love . For

674.text:
now it’s a mystery, but Rhaegar saying Lyanna’s
name with his last breath would add something

679.text: beautiful and tragic to this vision.

683.text:
Dany sees a “blue-eyed king” raise a “red
sword” that glows “like sunset”.

687.text:
This is probably the blue-eyed King Stannis
Baratheon raising his burning sword on the

692.text:
beach at Dragonstone, back when Melisandre
was trying to convince everyone that Stannis

699.text:
The king in the vision casts “no shadow”,
which probably hints at the magic shadow creature

703.text:
with Stannis’ face that Melisandre conjures
to kill Renly.

707.text:
A second way to interpret this vision is that
it could be an image of the future, of the

712.text:
true Azor Ahai – like, maybe Jon Snow in
the books will be resurrected not as the same

718.text:
guy he was before like in the show, but as
something different.

722.text:
He could have the blue eyes of a wight, his
sword could burn, transformed as Lightbringer,

727.text:
and he could be a king as the King in the
North – so maybe he could fit this vision

734.text:
Dany sees “A cloth dragon” swaying “on
poles amidst a cheering crowd”, which Dany

739.text: later says is called “a mummer’s dragon”.

742.text:
So remember Aegon, Rhaegar’s infant son
who died in Robert’s Rebellion?

746.text:
Well in the books, Varys and Illyrio claim
to have secretly saved Aegon and to’ve raised

751.text:
him to be a perfect king – there’s this
whole big conspiracy to put Aegon on the Iron

755.text:
Throne – but the thing is, the evidence
suggests that this Aegon Targaryen isn’t

760.text:
Aegon Targaryen at all – the kid’s a fake
– making him, symbolically, a mummer’s

767.text:
So it’s very interesting that the Undying
call Dany “slayer of lies”.

772.text:
Maybe Dany will be the one to reveal Varys
and Illyrio’s deceptions.

775.text:
Check out the Varys video for more on this
conspiracy.

777.text:
Then Dany sees “a great stone beast” taking
wing “From a smoking tower” and “breathing

783.text:
This one is tricky but it’s probably related
to Melisandre’s talk of waking a dragon

787.text:
from stone at the island of Dragonstone . Mel
wanted to sacrifice a young boy called Edric

793.text:
Storm, use his kingsblood to wake a stone
dragon , but Edric is saved by Davos and it

798.text:
doesn’t end up happening, so perhaps this
is another example of a prophecy averted.

804.text:
Dany sees “Her silver” “trotting through
the grass, to a darkling stream beneath a

807.text:
sea of stars”, which seems to be Dany on
her horse on her wedding night to Drogo.

812.text:
Dany sees “A corpse” standing “at the
prow of a ship, eyes bright in his dead face,

820.text: This could be a bunch of people.

821.text:
Theon Greyjoy comes to mind – standing on
a ship, looking like a corpse after his torture

826.text: by Ramsay, which was much worse in the books.

829.text:
It could also be book character Victarion,
a corpse in the sense that he’s probably

833.text: doomed to die in Slaver’s Bay.

835.text:
Or it could be Jon Connington, looking dead
and grey because of the greyscale taking over

841.text: It’s hard to be sure with this vision.

843.text:
Dany sees “A blue flower” growing “from
a chink in a wall of ice”, filling “the

849.text:
The “wall of ice” has gotta be the Wall,
right?

853.text:
As for the flower, blue “winter roses”
are often associated with Lyanna Stark . What’s

857.text: at the Wall that’s connected to Lyanna?

863.text:
The imagery of Jon filling the air with sweetness
in Dany’s vision might again support the

867.text: idea of a romance between the two.

870.text:
Dany sees “Shadows” whirling and dancing
“inside a tent, boneless and terrible”,

875.text:
and this is the tent where Mirri Maz Duur
performs the magic that kills the unborn Rhaego

880.text:
and leaves Drogo living but mindless
Dany sees “A little girl” running “barefoot

885.text:
toward a big house with a red door” , so
this is that house in Braavos again.

890.text:
Dany sees “Mirri Maz Duur” shrieking in
flames, “a dragon bursting from her brow”.

895.text:
So this is the fire where Dany hatches her
dragons – leaving Mirri to burn inside the

901.text:
Dany sees “the bloody corpse of a naked
man” bouncing and dragging “Behind a silver

907.text:
The corpse is the wineseller who tries to
poison Dany under the orders of Varys in Book

913.text:
When he’s caught, as punishment, he’s
dragged behind Dany’s horse until he dies

923.text:
In Book 1, Khal Drogo hunts for a hrakkar,
a “great white lion” that lives in the

928.text:
Dothraki Sea . Drogo succeeds, brings back
a dead lion , and makes a big cloak out of

934.text:
The cloak makes Dany feel closer to Drogo
after his death . So this lion running in

939.text: the vision is presumably that same lion.

942.text:
There is a different interpretation, though
– some people argue that Jaime is a Lannister

945.text:
lion and he wears the white cloak of a Kingsguard,
so maybe he also symbolically fits with this

952.text:
“Beneath the Mother of Mountains, a line
of naked crones” creep “from a great lake

957.text:
and” kneel “shivering before [Daenerys],
their grey heads bowed”.

961.text:
These crones are the dosh khaleen of Vaes
Dothrak, the Dothraki city.

966.text:
In the show, Dany has already visited here
twice, but in the books she hasn’t made

971.text:
There’ll surely be differences between the
show and book versions, but this vision sounds

976.text:
pretty similar to the show, with the Dothraki
kneeling before Daenerys.

980.text:
In her final vision, Dany sees “Ten thousand
slaves lift[ing] bloodstained hands as she

985.text:
race[s] by on her silver, riding like the
wind”, with the slaves crying “Mother!”.

991.text:
This is the scene from Book and Season 3 where
Dany is crowded by the freed slaves of Yunkai.

996.text:
In the vision they reach for her, touch her,
tug at her cloak, the hem of her skirt, wanting

1000.text:
her fire her life and then Dany snaps out
of it and sees all the corpsy gross Undying

1006.text:
warlocks swarming her , grabbing her, apparently
trying to kill her to take her power and her

1011.text:
dragons , so Dany’s dragon Drogon kills
them all and burns down the House of the Undying

1016.text: – which may be the fire for death.

1019.text:
But yeah those are the visions in the books,
but let’s also have a look at the visions

1025.text:
In the show, Dany has three quick visions
in the House of the Undying – first, Dany

1029.text:
sees the throne room in King’s Landing,
which appears to have been burned.

1033.text:
The roof’s gone, and snow is falling onto
the Iron Throne.

1038.text:
In the books, it may be Cersei’s wildfire
explosion that burns the Red Keep, though

1042.text:
in the show the wildfire only burns the Sept
so, at least in the show, we might have a

1048.text:
second burning, caused, perhaps, by Dany’s
dragons.

1051.text:
Also we have this moment of Dany reaching
out to touch the Throne, but then leaving

1056.text:
just before she grabs it – maybe hinting
that Dany might never quite take the Throne.

1062.text:
Dany then sees the Wall, and it does seem
likely that Dany will go there some time – cause

1066.text:
someone needs to destroy the white walkers’
army of the dead, and Dany’s dragons do

1072.text:
Finally, Dany enters a tent, and sees her
love Drogo, and the son they never had, Rhaego.

1078.text:
It’s a touching moment where Dany pauses
to reconnect with her past, but she soon moves

1085.text:
Her visions end, and she kills Pyat Pree with
fire, much like the books.

1091.text: What have we learned from all this?

1093.text:
We’ve seen that visions and dreams in Thrones
can accurately predict the future – like

1097.text:
this vision of the Red Wedding, and this one
of the slaves of Yunkai.

1100.text:
But we’ve also seen that visions and prophecies
can be wrong – the prophecy of the stallion

1105.text:
who mounts the world failed, and Rhaegar was
wrong about the prince that was promised,

1109.text:
and this thing with the stone dragon seems
not to have happened.

1112.text:
Even when they are true, visions and prophecies
can be so vague, and interpreted in so many

1117.text:
ways, that they’re usually not helpful for
the characters of the story, in fact they

1122.text:
can be harmful – would Mirri have killed
Rhaego if it weren’t for the prophecy of

1126.text: the stallion that mounts the world?

1128.text:
Would Rhaegar have run off with Lyanna if
it weren’t for the prince that was promised?

1132.text:
. Chasing after prophecies has caused all
sorts of madness and death – as one character

1136.text:
puts it, “Prophecy will bite your prick
off every time”.

1140.text:
But, “Still…”, there are some tantalising
hints here.

1144.text:
It looks like love and fire and treason are
in Dany’s future, which could very well

1148.text: connect to Azor Ahai, maybe Jon Snow.

1152.text:
As a slayer of lies, Dany may be an enemy
of Varys and his supposed Aegon Targaryen.

1158.text:
And it seems likely that she’ll go to the
Wall to fight against the white walkers.

1163.text:
And, if nothing else, it’s pretty cool to
get these glimpses of the past with Rhaegar
